Parameters of a survival model

Source: R/params.R
params_surv.Rd

Create a list containing the parameters of a single fitted parametric survival model.

params_surv(coefs, dist, aux = NULL)

Arguments

coefs

A list of length equal to the number of parameters in the survival distribution. Each element of the list is a matrix of samples from the posterior distribution of the regression coefficients used to predict a given parameter.
dist

Character vector denoting the parametric distribution. See "Details".
aux

Auxillary arguments used with splines. See "Details".

Value

An object of class "params_surv", which is a list containing coefs, dist, and n_samples. n_samples is equal to the number of rows in each element of coefs, which must be the same. The list may also contain aux, if a spline model is fit.

Details

The types of distributions that can be specified are:

  • exponential or exp Exponential distribution

  • weibull or weibull.quiet Weibull distribution

  • gamma Gamma distribution

  • lnorm Lognormal distribution

  • gompertz Gompertz distribution

  • llogis Log-logistic distribution

  • gengamma Generalized gamma distribution

  • survspline Survival splines

Auxillary arguments for spline models should be specified as a list containing the elements:

knots

A numeric vector of knots.

scale

A character vector of length 1 denoting the survival outcome to be modeled as a spline function. Options are "log_cumhazard", for the log cummulative hazard; "log_hazard" for the log hazard rate; "log_cumodds" for the log cummulative odds; and "inv_normal" for the inverse normal distribution function.

timescale

If "log" (the default), then survival is modeled as a spline function of log time; if "identity", then it is modeled as a spline function of time.

Examples

library("flexsurv")
fit <- flexsurvreg(Surv(futime, fustat) ~ 1, data = ovarian, dist = "weibull")
params <- params_surv(coefs = list(shape = fit$res.t["shape", "est", drop = FALSE],
                                   scale = fit$res.t["scale", "est", drop = FALSE]),
                     dist = fit$dlist$name)
print(params)
#> $coefs
#> $coefs$shape
#>             est
#> shape 0.1026105
#> 
#> $coefs$scale
#>            est
#> scale 7.111038
#> 
#> 
#> $dist
#> [1] "weibull.quiet"
#> 
#> $n_samples
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "params_surv"
